author: @dannyhameeteman
text: If you do not want to render the last plane always on top of the other planes, add the following piece of code:          # Enable depth test         glEnable(GL_DEPTH_TEST)         # Accept fragment if it closer to the camera than the former one         glDepthFunc(GL_LESS)   source: http://www.opengl-tutorial.org/beginners-tutorials/tutorial-4-a-colored-cube/

author: @nictanghe98
text: Oh i ws dissapointed on the whole zoom thing. That wasent actualy a zoom that is moving the cube along the Y axis  I whould realy like to know how to actually zoom as normaly up and down moves you along that axis.  (zoom is a camera movement not an object movement)  After a quick google i found that you can do an actual zoom with glViewport (offset_X, offset_Y, screen_X, screen_Y)
